title: Hans Eysenck
summary: Hans Jürgen Eysenck[1] (/ˈaɪzɛŋk/; 4 March 1916 – 4 September 1997) was a German-born British psychologist who spent his professional career in Great Britain. He is best remembered for his work on intelligence and personality, although he worked on other issues in psychology.[2][3] At the time of his death, Eysenck was the living psychologist most frequently cited in the peer-reviewed scientific journal literature.[4][5] A 2019 study found him to be the third most controversial of 55 intelligence researchers.[6]
